item.title: [NOT] Welcome to /biz/ - Business & Finance — 1 replies
item.content:encoded:
[NOT] Welcome to /biz/ - Business & Finance

Open thread • Replies: 1

OP

This board is for the discussion of topics related to business, economics, financial markets, securities, currencies (including cryptocurrencies), commodities, etc -- as well as topics relating to starting and running a business.

Discussions of government policy must be strictly limited to economic policies (fiscal and monetary). Discussions of a political nature should be posted on >>>/pol/. Global Rule 3 is also obviously in effect.

Note: /biz/ is NOT a place for ADVERTISING or SOLICITING. Do NOT use it to promote your business, ventures, or anything you may have an interest in. Anything that looks remotely like advertising or soliciting will be removed. Begging/asking (including tipping) for cryptocurrencies or asking for money/capital is also strictly forbidden.

Latest replies

60278993
Check the catalog before posting a new thread!Reply to existing threads about a topic instead of starting a new one. Mods will delete obvious duplicate threads and spam without notice.

When did the US government/banking system NOT devalue the dollar? You can look at US monetary history as a sequence of changes all designed to allow endless devaluation of the dollar. The current administration is not going to hit upon devaluing the dollar as some kind of new strategy. It has been THE deliberate operational strategy for fleecing the public for more than a hundred years. Gold and silver were merely obstacles that needed to be pushed out of the way. They don't need to revalue gold or silver to continue doing what they have been doing for a century. In fact, as you indicate, they have no choice now. All roads lead to hyperinflation.

61856820
>>61856778
>How the US government or Federal Reserve "values" gold on its books obviously has no effect on the market price of gold at the moment. Disagree?
Correct, simply "revaluing" gold on their books is just an accounting trick and does nothing.

I'm suggesting that the government will effectively devalue the dollar. They've already devalued it from $2000 to $5000. What's two more doublings?

It reduces the cost of servicing their debt by 80% and will happen one way or another as Trump wants yield curve control (lowered interest rates) because they can't allow the US Treasury long rates to go above 5% of it starts a cascade of a debt spiral.

There is NO money in the social security "trust fund" so all the new boomer entitlements need to be covered by money printing.

Much of the government revenue comes from taxes collected from rising equity prices, hence the "Dow 50000" comment. A recession that market corrects, and results in job losses, cuts government revenues while increasing expenditures for supports and stimulus.

We are sailing into a perfect storm.

>>61856418
>>61856774
Latvia has something called a "tier 3 pension pillar" but once your money goes in you cannot get it back no matter what until retirement and any capital gains are taxed at 25.5% when you start withdrawals.
If your employer matches your contributions from your AFTER tax wages the matching is taxed at 25.5% up front.
And you can only invest in managed funds that invest mostly in Latvian and E.U. bonds - so if the S&P is up 20% this year you will be up like 6%.
Americans have it good, especially with the Roth IRA.

Open thread • Replies: 247

OP

Welcome to /XMR/ Monero General, dedicated to the discussion of the world's most widely adopted privacy coin.

XMR payments are anonymous, low-fee, and fully fungible. Users can send and receive XMR globally without having to worry about tainted coins. Battle-tested privacy tech (Ring Signatures, Stealth Addresses and RingCT) ensures that critical TX data cannot be gleaned from the Monero blockchain; the TX history of all XMR users is kept hidden, with TXs being optionally transparent via the aid of a view key.

XMR ensures low TX fees by employing a dynamic block size that can "stretch" to easily accommodate sudden TX spikes.

XMR's mining algorithm, RandomX, is optimized for devices using general-purpose CPUs e.g. desktops, laptops, smartphones, tablets, keeping the barrier to entry low and ASICs out of the equation.

XMR's tail emission - 0.6 XMR per block forever - incentivizes for-profit miners to keep mining, helping boost long-term network security. This constant linear inflation trends to zero and is offset by coin loss.

XMR has proven to be the only altcoin capable of overcoming BTC's network effect by driving it out of the darknet economy BTC dominated for over 10 years. XMR is also starting to overtake BTC in clearnet commerce as well.

If you still have questions, feel free to ask. A MoneroChad will be with you shortly.

XMR Redpill: https://youtube.com/watch?v=wq6w03E2DS4

BUY XMR: https://monero.eco/exchanges/
Crypto ATMs: https://coinatmradar.com/

XMR Resources: https://monero.observer/resources/

XMR Stats: https://moneroj.net

USE XMR: https://cryptwerk.com/pay-with/xmr/

OFFICIAL WEBSITE: https://getmonero.org

MINING:

item.title: [ETH] I think I accidentally built a chain that can’t stall — 22 replies
item.content:encoded:
[ETH] I think I accidentally built a chain that can’t stall

Open thread • Replies: 22

OP

Been working on a blockchain design alone for ~1 year. Not a fork. Not based on ETH or Cosmos. Entirely custom protocol.
noticed something strange while running validator simulations tonight.
Even when all validators go offline, the chain continues producing blocks.
Not fake blocks. Protocol-generated blocks. Deterministic. Verifiable. No consensus break.
This wasn’t originally the goal. It emerged from how ticket burning and slot timing interact.
Current properties:
> 3-second slots
> leader selection via burned tickets (PoAsh)
> protocol generates blocks if leader fails or no tickets eligible
> chain never halts, even under 100% validator failure
> validators can’t stall the chain intentionally or accidentally

Still has bugs (pic related), but if this holds under edge cases, it removes one of the oldest failure modes in blockchain design: liveness collapse.
Still early. Still finding edge cases I didn’t anticipate.

Next test is validator rejoin after extended protocol-only operation.

posting devlogs elsewhere 'cause I kept losing simulation history when threads expire.

devlogs: https://t [dot] me/+2SXaDc7CMYc4MTZh
posting validator logs, failures, and protocol behavior as they happen. easier than losing everything when threads expire.
can answer here too, but threads vanish.

Latest replies

61856955
>>61856571
>Been working on a blockchain design alone for ~1 year.
Autism?

61856928
>>61856917
no distribution yet. still focused on getting protocol behavior stable first. economic layer and supply model come after consensus is proven.

61856917
>>61856654
>>61856571
Can you airdrop us altcoin crash victims each 0.1% of the supply at least?

61856723
>>61856716
centralized and doesnt scale, so in other words useless dogshit.

61856716
>>61856705
protocol blocks don’t introduce authority. they’re deterministic and computed independently by every node from prior state. no single node controls them.

validators still perform the economically meaningful function — proposing transaction-containing blocks and advancing state beyond empty continuity.

61856712
>>61856695
right now the focus is getting the consensus layer stable and predictable under failure conditions. the main property i'm targeting is guaranteed continuity — the chain advances regardless of validator availability.

use case-wise, that makes it more reliable as base infrastructure. most chains assume validators are always present and coordinated. removing that assumption reduces fragility during outages, network partitions, or coordination failures.
not trying to outcompete eth or sol on throughput or ecosystem initially. goal is a minimal base layer with strong liveness guarantees and deterministic behavior. economic layer and higher-level features come after consensus is proven stable.

simulator is partially working now. still testing validator reintegration, fork resistance, and edge cases. if behavior holds, public testnet this year is realistic.

61856705
>>61856571
sounds very centralized (so useless).

61856697
>>61856691
protocol advances independently of validators. validators only affect economic state transitions, not continuity.

61856695
>>61856681
What further features of the blockchain do you have in mind? Use cases?

What do you anticipate in terms or use cases and can you compare your end goal vs a current state of x competitor chain that you feel is ripe for disruption?

How far from a release of a beta do you think you are? This year?

61856691
>validator
fiat with extra steps

61856681
>>61856673
not really something you can sell. value comes from the network existing and being used, not from owning the design. still focused on getting protocol behavior correct first.

61856673
>>61856571
Probably bullshit, but if it's not just sell the tech and make alot of money

61856669
It added ">17 ' by itdelf. Don't knowwhy. Must have been a glitch. I swear I didn't write it myself.

61856654
>>61856647
>17
no coin yet. still building and testing protocol behavior. economic layer comes after consensus layer is stable.
right now just making sure protocol behaves deterministically under failure conditions.

61856647
>>61856571
Just shill me the coin ranjeesh don't sell me the moon

61856641
youre a fucking nerd

61856633
>>61856613
protocol blocks are deterministic functions of prior chain state and slot number. every node computes the same block independently when no validator proposes one, so no fork emerges.
validators resume normal block production on top of that state when they return. protocol blocks preserve continuity but don’t replace validator economic function.

61856613
>>61856601
How do they sync later? This is going to be running simultaneously on many nodes. If it is so predictable it doesn't require more than one node then I think the advantages of decentralization are lost

61856611
AI sloppa

61856604
>>61856571
>Not X, not Y, but Z.

>It's not X, it's Y

Thanks chatgpt, if I wanted to read ai gen shit, I would just message it myself.

61856601
>>61856588
current simulator shows protocol blocks advancing state root deterministically when no validator is eligible. still testing validator reintegration and fork resistance. bugs in pic related came from vault state transition edge case.

61856588
Well have our boys in the lab run the data and get back to you when we have some results. Son, you might have just saved western civilization.
